title: 114_hr3869
content: The Act titled "State and Local Cyber Protection Act of 2015" mandates coordination between state and local entities with the National Cybersecurity and Communications Integration Center. The Homeland Security Act of 2002 is amended to include a new subsection focusing on State and Local Coordination on Cybersecurity. The Center will assist State and local governments in identifying information system vulnerabilities and security protections. The Homeland Security Act of 2002 is amended to include a new subsection focusing on State and Local Coordination on Cybersecurity. The Center will provide tools, resources, and guidelines related to information security for State and local governments, working with officials to ensure effective implementation and resilience of information systems. The Center will provide operational and technical cybersecurity training, privacy and civil liberties training, and assistance to State and local governments in implementing tools and resources for information security. The Center will assist State and local governments in diagnosing and mitigating cyber threats, analyzing information security data, conducting operational evaluations, developing vulnerability disclosure policies, and providing awareness of tools and products. The Department aims to inform State and local governments about information security tools and resources. Training on privacy and civil liberties will align with Fair Information Practice Principles and limit the use of cybersecurity information related to individuals. The disclosure of cybersecurity risks and incidents should only include necessary information to protect information systems, minimize impact on privacy and civil liberties, ensure data integrity by removing obsolete information, and safeguard sensitive data from unauthorized access. The national cybersecurity and communications integration center must protect sensitive information, maintain confidentiality of cyber threat indicators, and comply with legal and privacy protections. Congressional oversight is required to assess the effectiveness of these activities within 2 years of the enactment of the Act. The national cybersecurity and communications integration center seeks feedback from State and local governments on information security effectiveness. The House of Representatives passed the information required under this subsection on December 10, 2015. Clerk: KAREN L. HAAS.
